case_data.summary:
On April 16, 2007, Plaintiff, represented by private attorney Mark E. Merin, filed a 42 U.S.C. § 1983 class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California in order to challenge the Sheriff's policies and practices concerning the use of strip and visual body cavity searches in Solano County Jail. Plaintiff, who was arrested on minor criminal charges, complained that he was subsequently strip searched in a group with ten other persons pursuant to a policy under which officers routinely subjected custodial detainees to strip and visual body cavity searches prior to arraignment and in the absence of any reasonable suspicion that the detainees possessed contraband or weapons.

Plaintiff claimed that such a policy violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution as well as California state law. To remedy the alleged violations, Plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief, monetary damages, and class certification.

On July 29, 2008, Plaintiffs filed their First Amended Complaint to add four new plaintiffs. The hearing and motions regarding class certification were then repeatedly pushed back as the parties continued discovery and settlement negotiations.

On September 25, 2009, the parties presented their settlement to the court. The settlement was approved 4 days later. Parties agreed that class certification was inappropriate because defendants had revised their policy on November 20, 2003 and again in 2007 to comply with federal law. To remedy the individual violations that had occurred in spite of the policy revisions, the defendants agreed to pay $12,500 to each plaintiff, $100,000 in attorney fees, and $750-$1000 to each person who contacted plaintiff's attorney alleging that they fell within the allegations in the complaint. The defendants paid a total of $210,000, and on September 29, 2009, the case was dismissed with prejudice.

18 This case was before the undersigned on January 30, 2008, for hearing on defendants’
19 motion to compel the California Department of Justice’s compliance with a subpoena duces
20 tecum pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 45(c)(2)(B)(1).  Specifically, defendants seek to compel
21 information relating to plaintiff’s criminal history from the California Department of Justice
22 (“DOJ”) on the basis that it is relevant to the claims and defenses in this suit.  
23 This federal question case concerns claims brought pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §§ 1983 and 
24 1988, for alleged constitutional violations by defendants in connection with strip searches at the
25 Solano County Jails.  On October 17, 2007, defendants served a subpoena duces tecum on the
26 custodian of records at the California DOJ.  The subpoena sought records “concerning the
1

1 criminal history of Michael James Todd,” the plaintiff in this action.  See Exh. A to Robertson
2 Decl.  Notice of the subpoena was completed on all parties, including the plaintiff through his
3 attorney of record.  
4 Defendants seek the subpoenaed records in order to obtain an accurate and objective
5 summary of the criminal history records of the plaintiff given the nature of the claims asserted. 
6 More specifically, a primary issue in this case is whether the strip search of plaintiff was
7 constitutional.  In determining whether a strip search is warranted inside a jail context, officers
8 must consider several factors, including the nature of the offense and detainee’s prior arrest
9 record.  See Giles v. Ackerman, 746 F.2d 614, 617 (9th Cir. 1984), overruled on other grounds, 
10 Hodgers-Durgin v. De La Vina, 199 F.3d 1037 (9th Cir. 1999); Way v. County of Ventura, 445
11 F.3d 1157, 1162 (9th Cir. 2006).  
12 Plaintiff has filed no objection to subpoena.  The Department of Justice has objected to
13 production on the basis of state law.  See Cal. Pen. Code §§ 11175, 11076, 11105 and 11141, et
14 seq., Cal. Civ. Code § 1798, et seq.; Cal. Evid. Code § 1040.  
15 For the reasons stated on the record at the hearing, the court finds the DOJ’s objections
16 unavailing.  See Pagano v. Oroville Hosp., 145 F.R.D. 683, 687 (E.D. Cal. 1993); Fed. R. Civ. P.
17 1 (“These rules govern the procedure in the United States district courts in all suits of a civil
18 nature. . . .”); see also Doubleday v. Ruh, 149 F.R.D. 601, 612 (E.D. Cal. 1993) (holding that
19 “under principles of federalism, state legislatures are not free to legislate what a federal court
20 may order produced in the way of documentation” and that Cal. Pen. Code § 11101, et seq. did
21 not bar plaintiff from obtaining the requested information).  
22 ////
23 ////
24 ////
25 ////

1 Accordingly, the court grants defendants’ motion to compel pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P.
2 45(c)(2)(B).  The DOJ shall produce the documents responsive to defendants’ October 17, 2007,
3 subpoena duces tecum within ten days.
